Nah you've got it all wrong. People in this class a) Underprivileged kids b) Kids who did not excel in mathematics but did in other areas (namely science because it's MIT) c) Kids who did not excel in school at all but did something amazing like groundbreaking research or invention d) People retaking the course because they're scared they didn't do good enough for MIT standards. In any case these are probably a minority of kids

avatarmage34 what exactly are the standards for MIT Calc I? i wasnt aware MIT was in a different universe where calculus was different. and i highly doubt each and everyone of those kids made a discovery or an outstanding project that got a lot of attention because whenever one of those things happen theyre always on a magazine/web article. and why would underprivileged kids be going to a school that has a tuition that has a lower-middle/middle class salary

Adam Resh Well I got a 5 on AP Calc BC and this course seems a tad bit harder. Not a whole lot but still harder. Like I said not each and every one made an outstanding discovery. Also not every great discovery is published in common magazines or even websites. Most just pass by in scientific journals. Anyway this is probably 5% of that class or less. Also as I said underprivileged kids probably make up a good number of this class. Most people don't pay full tuition. Pretty much everyone who's family makes 90k or less gets a full ride these days and that INCLUDES living expenses as well. Yeah it's all over the news that these top colleges are super expensive, but they conveniently leave out that a more than 75% of kids usually are receiving a discount if not a free education.

Adam Resh Regardless my overall point is that MIT does pick academically very strong students. Just look at the stats of the admitted class. But they don't pick robots. They look for students who they deem will be successful in the future and will bring success to their alma matter. So no the person with the highest score doesn't always get in. The secret to getting is not pure luck but rather a strong academic background, a recipe for success indicated by  particular passions in extracurricular activities, and yes a bit of luck ;)

Adam Resh This appears to be a very standard first year calculus course. Something to this effect would be offered regardless of which university you go to, prestigious or otherwise. I believe the intent of those course is to give students an understanding of why various calculus tricks work and leads into discussions of how they work and how they do not work. Or at least that's what I have seen from my experience in several universities.

Nahid Akbar But yah, this can probably get more high level. When I did this course in my undergrad uni almost a decade ago, there was a lot more proving of theorems and a lot less calculus techniques were discussed. The professors just gave us basic limit theories and we were assessed on our ability to do do the proofs and derivations of the actual actual calculus techniques and tiny bit in our ability to use these techniques. But then again, that course had a bad rep from non-maths students of what they learn not being so useful and from what I heard, was changed soon after. Most people who take these course are not mathematicians. They are economists and physicists and engineers etc. For them, application and learning when to when when not to use these techniques are more important than how these techniques work.

Nahid Akbar 1. The reason this course is rigorous is because it covers calc 1 and 2 in one semester not a year like almost every other university does.  2. If this class did any more rigorous proofs then it would be going into the category of graduate level math courses and that's not the point of an introductory calc 1/2 course.
